Key Match Events: Raphinha had an excellent early opportunity to score after latching on to a long ball over the top from Rodrygo, but Costa Rica keeper Patrick Sequeira came quickly off his line to snuff out the danger.

Brazil thought they had got the breakthrough in the 30th minute when a free kick was flicked on by Rodrygo into the path of Marquinhos, who poked it in at the far post but the goal was disallowed for offside after a lengthy VAR delay.
Lucas Paquetá rattled the woodwork with a long-range effort in the 63rd minute before a venomous Guilherme Arana strike was kept out by a fine save from Sequeira.
Pre-Game Insights: Vinícius Junior said after the game, ‘We know we can improve, we have to improve. I also know what I can improve, evolve and do for our team.’
Post-Match Reflections: Vinícius Junior said, ‘New coach, new players, everything takes time. Our fans want everything immediately done, but we’re going little by little. In the next game, I’m sure we’ll play much better because we now already understand what the competition will be like, what the pitch, what the referees will be like.’
Miscellaneous Highlights: Colombia lead Group D following their 2-1 win over Paraguay earlier on Monday. James Rodríguez evoked memories of his breakthrough performance at the 2014 World Cup on Monday after the Colombia midfielder set up both goals in his team’s victory.
Others: Brazil missed a string of chances and were left to rue a lack of quality in the final third after they were held 0-0 by Costa Rica in their Copa América Group D opener in Los Angeles on Monday.

Frustration has become the norm for Brazil in recent years. After 18 months of upheaval in the federation, dugout and squad, they have fallen to sixth in South American qualifying for the 2026 World Cup.
